moves.1. e4: This is the first of a hopefully short series of games where I lose primarily after a single blunder. During my current slump in form and rating this has happened a little too often for my liking. I hope that others can learn from my mistakes. This particular game is I believe one of the classic finishes that I totally overlooked.
moves.1... d5: Scandinavian, my standard response as black to e4 with some mixed success
moves.2. exd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qd8: Perhaps not the best response but it is the third most common on the gameknot database.
moves.4. Bc4 Nc6 5. d3: opening a nice line for the dsb, perhaps anticipating Bf4 followed by Nb5 (or d5) threatening Nxc7+
moves.5... Nf6 6. Nf3 Bg4 7. h3 Bh5: This is all fairly standard stuff so far, nothing much to indicate what is to come.
moves.8. Be3 Ne5: Appears to threaten the white knight and the lsb which I was hoping to take, as the knight is pinned to the queen, my knight appears to be immune, however appearances can be deceptive as we will see.
moves.9. Nxe5: I rashly assumed this was a blunder, I had anticipated the fork from Nxf7 but when I looked at the possibility of Bxf7, for some reason I overlooked that the knight was attacking d7
moves.9... Bxd1: This is a complete blunder that loses immediately, better was Bg6 which at least protected the f pawn.
moves.10. Bxf7#:
And there it is. Well played Mody7. 


The moral of this tale is if you think you are safe, look again at least once more.
